The carnitas are a wonderful staple item, and the short-rib tacos are a unique twist that strikes the perfect balance between traditional flavors and avant-garde technique. Portion sizes are generous for tacos, and the extensive menu means there's always something new to try. From the comforting chicken soup to the outlandish grilled calamari, there are an endless list of new flavors to explore. 

My only request would be for a hotter tomato-based salsa. Currently, the mango-habanero is the spiciest salsa offered, and its consistency is a bit too smooth for my tastes.
author: Braden S.

description:
Roses are red,
Tortillas can be blue, 
$10 taco, tecate, and a shot of tequila?
Tacolicious, I love you.
author: Julianne M.

description:
Pasion Margarita and bring some friends to share some tacos! So good! They do have grilled fish tacos, which are not on the menu. Also, the mussels on the appetizer list are great!

Sit at the bar and hope you get Jacob the bartender!
author: Wheat K.

description:
Love this place.  Everything I've tried here is delicious.  

My favorites are the fish tacos, veggie tacos, watermelon/heirloom tomato salad and chilaquiles.  

The only reason I'm not giving it 5 stars is because there's always something a little off about the service.
author: Gabriella K.

description: In San Francisco for the day....stopped by this location on Valencia for a quick lunch. The food was good, but a bit expensive at $68 for 8 tacos, two drinks and chips & salsa.  Our server, a young girl with jet-black hair and a nose ring, took out order and then never bothered to come back. Drinks never came....and then the food server brought our order 15min later. The server went to get our drinks as well. He saved us from her lousy service and personal skills.  Also, the bar tender was a very cool guy.  Giving this place a "4," but will change it to a "5" if they fire her!
author: Meg S.

description:
Can screaming, photo-flashing Marina people ruin your experience at a new restaurant? Yes, of course.

Tacolicious (and the adjoining bar Mosto) have answered a long-time Mission question mark. If you build a beautifully designed restaurant and bar and served good food and drinks will hordes of lingering Marina douchebags flock to it. Yes, they will. Thanks, Tacolicious, you win the bet!

The entire place was seemingly designed to attract non-94110-ers here and it worked. This place is a meeting place for large groups of people who look like they might admire Paris Hilton. 

As a party of 2 going in for dinner on a Saturday night we were cluelessly mistaken that we could just walk in, like any taqueria within a mile radius. No, we had to leave our names and slink off to the bar Mosto to waste an hour drinking margaritas until we were finally called.

Mosto felt like Hell on Earth. My version of Hell on Earth is struggling to find 2 bar seats while Michael Jackson is blaring at 200db and everyone nearby is screaming at one another. I pretty much lost my voice trying to talk to my girlfriend. Our bartender came off snobby to my girlfriend as she was puzzled why the food and drinks at Tacolicious were not available at Mosto. I sort of got it that they wanted to do things different in the bar but he pissed her off. The drink selection was overwhelming so we just went for the house margaritas. Although they were tasty I got no buzz. Also, the bartender ignored her $20 that she put down. Obviously hoping we would have to endure longer an keep buying.

After about 45 minutes this b.s., I checked in with the 2 (!!) hostesses to see how much longer until we got a seat. They were rude to me and gave me a bunch of runaround. Nevertheless about 15 minutes later one did find me in the bar and we finally got to sit down for food!

Our waitress seemed to be trained at Applebees as she was overly checking in on us. We were shell-shocked by this time. We finally made our food and drink decisions and I went to the bathroom. When I returned my girlfriend had her beets and a drink and I had nothing. Then the waitress re-appeared to ask me how it was going. Umm, can I have my over-priced drink, please?

We split 8 tacos and they were the delicious. I especially liked the fish taco. The rice was good but for $5 a little high.

I had to give up on conversation as an army of Paris Hiltons sat next to us and were screaming and being rude to the the help.

We left, bewildered and frustrated. 

Our first thought was that one day the SFPD would impose martial law in the Mission. Carefully they would examine IDs and reject any Marina people seeking to attend Mission restaurants. I Have A Dream.

I think I would give Tacolicious another shot. I am thinking about an early lunch on a weekday in the outdoor seating on a sunny day. There has to be a way to avoid the soul-crushing night crowds here.

And I would take the service with a grain of salt. the people who work there are forced to deal with loud assholes. It is no wonder they have gone robotic so early in the life of this restaurant.
author: Dave B.

description: The place is nice, clean and cozy but on the other hand it fills up really quick, it's super noisy and the most shocking part: is way too expensive for the food they offer, the tacos are nice but definitely nothing beyond that. For 2 adults and 2 small kids we paid $ 160... just for tacos, are you kidding me?
author: Hope L.

description:
Decent, but being a native from San Jose, paying top dollar for Mexican food is not what I'm accustomed to. If I want great Mexican food, I can get it anywhere in San Jose. 

Their dipping sauces were yummy. 

I think we ordered 2 plates of tacos + 2 non-alcoholic drinks = $40+. In San Jose, I can get something similar for ~$10 - $15.
author: Mia X.

description: I came here on Thursday at 2pm to get an order to go. I was told to order at the bar, the bartender didn't even acknowledge me and stood there as I tired to get his attention. I placed my order and got my food and left, only to realize that it was the wrong order so I went back. I told him he gave me the wrong order. Instead of just making my order he made snarky comments saying I said the wrong item it wasn't his fault. The service was unacceptable!
author: Mika L.

description:
I love coming here for brunch.  They have the best chips, the most amazing drinks, and fantastic tacos.  The servers (generally) seem to know what is gluten-free and what is not, and that's always a good thing.  

That said, i would give it 5 stars if they had better service in their outdoor area.  We have waited pretty good amounts of time for our drinks to come out to us out there.  Also, if only their Sunday brunch hostess was nicer - she once informed us as we stopped to say "hi" to another table of our friends, that we would need to wait up front because she "is in charge of all things 'table' related."  LOL  Alright little missy...someone needs a nap and an attitude adjustment.
author: Min M.

description:
Believe the hype.

Tacolicious is amazeballs the food is delicious and beautifully presented. 

This was my first visit, I am still talking about this experience with my friends in NY.  Yes they are all jealous.

The service was not amazing, but it was lunch. Our server was almost shy...?

The food was SO AMAZING.  Get the Tombo tuna tostada.  Get the taco of the day. Get the beer and shot braise chicken tacos.  Try the cod.  You will be blown away.

Tip: I was starving and only ate one taco and the Tombo appetizer and I was so full.  Four tacos is a shit ton of food.

I am so jealous San Franciscans have such amazing food choices.  I am not envious of the gentrification in The Mish, but this spot is tits!
author: James S.

description:
If there ever were a more aptly named restaurant, I don't know of it.  Tacolicious promises, and Tacolicious delivers.  (but they don't "deliver"-deliver, so don't be confused.  You can do take out though!)

I was lucky enough to try it on a sunny Friday for lunch, a time when it is not crowded and the lovely outdoor seating area can be fully enjoyed.  

The menu is made up of snacks, drinks, sides and tacos.  In other words, all of the essential food groups.  It's food that's meant for sharing, however it's so tasty that you won't want to share.  Conundrum!

I had the Pasion cocktail and that is one of the most interesting, refreshing drinks I have had in awhile.  Tart/spicy/sweet and salty all at once.  YUM!

Three of us shared the albacore tuna tostadas which I would highly recommend:  it's a large portion of sashimi-grade tuna on a small tostada with chipotle mayonnaise and large slices of avocado.  Next time I am getting an order all for myself!

We then got a selection of tacos to share - the butternut squash, rock cod, cochinita pibil (like carnitas but much better!) and bistec adobado.  You cannot go wrong with any of these, but the cochinita pibil was my favorite.

The space is lovely, every member of the staff was friendly and caring, and the space was bright, modern and welcoming.  Oh, and they have a huge selection of tequilas, so what more could you want?

In a neighborhood where there is literally a taco place on every corner (and more than a few in between), Tacolicious stands out as something new, accessible, affordable, and....say it with me...TACOLICIOUS!
author: Liz S.

description: Don't waste your time. The tacos aren't worth the bad attitude you get when you walk in the door and have to interact with the brain dead sorority girls working the front of house. They will laugh at you and tell you that the wait for a table is an hour and a half to two hours. But really it's half that. They just want you to go away. And if you have tough enough skin to wait it out and manage to actually eat a few of their white people "tacos"? Your tough skin will seem like tender veal compared to the dry, flavorless "tacos" you get. Seriously, don't waste you time. This place is popular in name only.
author: David H.

description:
After walking around the Mission for a modern Mexican restaurant with cocktails we decided to stop in here. The restaurant and bar were moderately busy. We sat at the bar and the bar tenders were incredibly rude and hostile. There were three of them working in a small corner of the bar, each of them more rude then the next. Getting a menu seemed like pulling teeth. Ordering was chaotic. We never got the feeling that anyone had taken our order though we had ordered and asked about our order twice. 
I know it's hard to find good staff in San Francisco but they really need to train their bar tenders in hospitality. No one should have to tolerate being treated so badly. The food we saw looked mediocre and small portions. We ended up walking out. I doubt they even noticed or cared. Good job!!
author: Victor L.

description:
The tacos were life-changing and the atmosphere at Tacolicious was really fun. We came here for lunch on a Sunday and the place was crowded, but the food looked so good we decided to wait. Glad we did. The place felt like a party. 

Food: The chips and salsa were really delicious. I also loved the trio of different salsas they brought out with our tacos. My favorite taco was their taco of the week--a Korean short rib. The flavor was explosive and the meat was extremely tender. I also enjoyed the shot-and-a-beer braised chicken taco. My friend got the traditional carnitas and fried local rock cod tacos, and he was happy too. The portions were generous. We also shared the asparagus a la plancha on the side, and it was smoky, perfectly charred, and extremely fresh.
author: Suzie D.

description: Definitely a fan of their concept. Really high quality taco ingredients and a well stocked bar. The wait time can often be a little overwhelming but they get the job done. Go here for some dope, modern tacos and a margarita. The guac could be a bit better and the service gets overwhelmed at times.
author: Milan T.

description:
Nursing a wee bit of a hangover today, Tacolicious hit the spot. The four of us ordered:

Beet Salad (did not have but friends said it was fresh, light and delicious. 
Pork Pozole (friend really liked it-hit the spot)
Camarones Diablo (again, friend loved it)
Grilled Squid Veracruz (my dish- awesome goodness. I'm on a low card diet and this was the best selection for me. 
Albondigas (not what my friend was expecting. He was expecting more of a broth and this was tomato based. It looked like pasta sauce. It was very spicy and very tasty. 

This place never disappoints. And soothes the soul.
author: Cindi C.

description:
If you want to eat mexican food in the Mission and you don't want it served by Mexicans, then this is the place for you. Coming in strong in the "overpriced and under-delivered" category is Tacolicious. Sure, it's pretty and they have tequila/margaritas. That accounts for the two stars I'm giving it. 

The salsa did not have a good flavor. The tacos were underwhelming. The plantains were dry and overcooked. You're not gonna fool me with your charming succulents and your nice floor tile! Life's too short to eat subpar mexican food!
author: Lisa Marie G.

description: Yes, the tacos are overpriced. Yes, this is in the mission and there are plenty of other taquerias you could go to. But seriously, one bite off of those carnitas tacos and I was in love. I sometimes dream of tacolicious' tacos and if I were pregnant I'd probably crave them for breakfast, lunch, and dinner--that's how amazing they are. I honestly don't mind paying $1 extra for a quality taco, with quality service, and at a beautiful location. I obviously still go to taco trucks, and they're bomb, but you don't go here just for the food, it's an overall great experience. I also recommend the guacamole and their grilled squid. Their margaritas are all amazing (and some spicy, if you're into that). The wait can be a little overwhelming on weekend nights, but there's usually space at the bar and you can have yummy drinks while you wait.
author: Rafaella S.

description:
They clearly imported this restaurant (including the waitstaff) from the marina... that being said, its ok white-people mexican. the appetizers kind of sucked in my opinion (the marina girl salad is exactly that- bland and expensive). the taquitos were so greasy and fatty.

the pick-your-own taco platter is the way to go for fancy tacos- good ingredients and Mosto is right next door when you get sick of the Marina scene.... its like being city-transported by crossing a doorframe
author: Carolina S.

description: Pretty mediocre. The tacos are ok, and its good that they tried some kind of creative meats, but in the end, the tacos are nothing special. The price isn't that bad in terms of sit down dining, but you are really just sitting down to street food. The mission, especially that part of the mission, are home to so many amazing taquerias, that this place isn't worth paying extra. The restaurant is really loud, which isn't great for conversations. Overall, Not a place to avoid outright, but not really worth going to either.
author: David F.

description:
I've had these tacos a few times and they're delicious! There are different types of tacos to choose from, but I'm a big fan of the grilled cod and butternut squash. But there is like 9-10 options to choose from. They bring out 3 types of sauces, I like the yellow which is hot. Plus you get chips and salsa when you sit down, so if you're starving you can munch on those. 

The thing that impressed me the most is the service. I wanted to send my valentine lunch to his work on Valentine's Day because I worked all day that day and emailed the manager at this restaurant. They don't normally do personal deliveries unless its a big order for a business. But as nice as Chris V was, he personally delivered to his work at lunch, without even knowing me and let me come in after I got out of work later that evening to pay. I was so grateful and pleased with how kind he was that I needed to yelp him and give him recognition. 

Thanks again Chris!
author: Jocelyn W.

description: The Tacolicious Food Truck was at a Centennial Celebration I attended on April 30th.  I was thrilled to see their taco options.  Unfortunately, I wasn't able to make up my mind so I ended up ordering a carnitas taco, a chicken taco, and a veggie taco.  They were all scrumptious!  My grandchildren were as crazy about the tacos as I was.  We can't wait to go and enjoy their food again!  When you go, don't pass up their avocado salsa!  Excellent!
author: Denise G.

description:
I LOVE the food.  Their rice, beans, plantains, salads, guacamole and salsa are all so ZESTY!  If you want flavor to punch you in the mouth on an adventure of texture, crunch, salty, sour, sweet, and above all else, ZEST, then this is the place for you.  I also recommend the delicious La Paloma, a fantastic mixture of tantalizing tequila and grapefruit with some other magic ingredients.  

The only thing I would warn you is that the wait for a table is usually at least 45 minutes to an hour.  So go when you aren't dying of hunger, take a deck of cards, and post up while you wait for a table at Mosto.
author: Jasmine F.

description:
i made a yelp account just to make a review about this place. 

we were told a 20 minute wait that was actually 40 minutes, just to pay $18 for the weakest most devoid of flavor chilaquiles i have ever ate; sweaty cardboard chips with super neutral refried beans and rice (like common, some seasoning?), a light mist of feta cheese =$11, then i asked for some carne asada. it came on the side, and they gave me a 3 small bits of the most flavorless steak i've ever encountered=$5

I guess i might have ordered the wrong thing, and they were busy so maybe less attention was paid to my food, but i would not risk ever going there again.
author: Jess N.

description:
Another SF spot with a long wait but totally worth it, especially if you like tequila. Next door is Mosto which is a tequila bar that serves snacks, so if the wait is over an hour (which is often is), you can hang right next door and try a flight of tequila or some delicious margaritas. 

Once you get seated I'd recommend getting the bistec abodabo taco and the braised short rib taco. If you don't like beef, that's unfortunate, but every taco I've had here is good so you really can't go wrong. 

Other things worth trying are the freshly made guacamole, the queso and the grilled squid appetizer. 

I've been here a lot. It's good.
author: Vamsi T.

description:
Just no, I have to question whether the folks giving this five stars have ever eaten Mexican or tex-mex before. Also it's bit disturbing to me to find families with little babies next to or with people chugging tequila. It probably makes me a prude but that's ok with me. It can get rather noisy with both the children, very loud music and the drinkers.

There's not much to say about the food, it was overpriced and didn't taste good. It's great they want to be organic but it just wasn't very good and we didn't finish most of our dishes. The tacos all had something wrong dry meat, over fried battered fish and I don't know if they actually know what a mole is.

The only thing that was nice was the decor but I go to restaurant to eat food not furniture shop.

Judging from the clientele I'm not the right demographic for this restaurant as I am not afraid to go to an actual Mexican restaurant or walk down Mission street.

But considering the excellent local press they have gotten (totally unrelated, the owner's wife is a writer at a local magazine) and the many new residents of the Mission who prefer even their ethnic food made  and served by people who look like them, I'm sure this will be a hit.
author: DeathandFood H.

description:
Great place for tacos. You won't be disappointed!
A group of friends and I were super skeptical at the name when someone suggested we go to Tacolicious. What? What kind of name is that? But it IS delicious. They have a great deal for groups -- we had 5 people and we got the 10 for $33 -- and we munched on chips and salsa and we were good. The taco fillings are all great but my favorite was chorizo and the braised beef. If I lived in San Fran I would empty my bank account eating here.
WARNING: If you DO decide to go for the 10 for $33 with a group, make sure people have cash because splitting the bill was sort of a hassle and we had to do all the calculations ourselves among our cards (thankfully we had a Berkeley MBA student with us!)
 Small pain for the good food, but just to be aware.
author: Alison S.

description:
Review sent to Tacolicious Manahpgement:

I wanted to provide you with some feedback from our visit last Friday evening to your Mission location.

First, your Chili Con Queso under the appetizers is absolutely awesome.  Also, your Guajillo Braised Beef Short Rib taco's are fabulous.

Second, however, your shot-and-a-beer braised chicken taco's which we had 3 of tasted overly cooked/ very dry and had a very nasty bad meat taste.  Also, the Carnitis taco had a long hair in it.  We had the drunken beans also and they were overly spiced and not edible.  Therefore, we left 4 taco's and beans and tried to notify our server, Elenora, but she ignored us.  Therefore, we paid our bill & left.  

I would go again for a beer and Chile con Queso, but probably not the main meal since it appeared your server didn't care that people were having problems with some of the food.

I don't like to complain, but it was "Date Night" and the food proved to put a strain on the dinner portion.
author: Herb B.

description:
Was hesitant about this place because it didn't seem authentic, and I already had my favorites...

But the food is pretty darn good. The chips, all the salsas, the agua fresca, the alcohol, and the tacos were all scrumptious. I was impressed. Would definitely return.

Be forewarned that there's typically a wait. Also, it's definitely on the louder side.
author: Thuan N.

description:
Modern atmosphere, great food, fast and friendly service, Tacolicious is a good choice for those wanting to try a modern take on Mexican food. 

They got us from the starter chips/salsa they serve when you arrive to the amazing sweet plantains (you have to try it, it is perfection in a plate) appetizer to everything else.

I had the camarones al diablo with a side of semi-traditional refried beans and I loved both. The camarones are cooked to perfection and the beans are so tasty you will find yourself "scraping" the little plate to make sure you got everything out of it. 

Certainly a new favorite for Mexican food in SF. The restaurant is pretty busy but things move quickly so it is definitely worth the wait.
author: Gisele M.

description: Food is great but service was awful.  The hostess quoted 45 mins and it took 1 hour 40 minutes.  After we followed up several times, the hostess finally sat 3 of us at a table for 2.  Our server was extremely rude and made us feel like we were the worst patrons.  We ordered $50 of food and drinks for each person and tipped 20% and left with a very bad feeling.
author: Elise G.

description: Solid place, but definitely overpriced. There taco Tuesdays are pretty good for your buck. Their tacos are real good, good qualification but again overpriced. I love the atmosphere, awesome patio. Great drink choices as well. They give you chips and salsa when you come, but most the time when I've been the service has been pretty slow.
author: Kiarash H.

description: Met some good friends there on Saturday evening and it took us over an hour and a half to be seated.  Hostess was not very concerned about getting us seated and they were seating other people before us that had been waiting a shorter time.  Giving it two stars because of the customer service. The food was not authentic be good.
author: Laura T.

description:
Not very Taco-licious, more like Taco-iocre.


good food but a predictable menu 
lacks vegetarian choices
really good chips/salsa
great selection of tequilas
overpriced for tacos
overcrowded with the Marina-style douches
nicely designed interior space
author: Shannon Z.

description: Okay, so I've eaten a lot of tacos in my time.  These were the good tacos i have eaten in my five years in California.  In fact everything from the decor, to the friendly servers, to my perfectly balanced margarita, was excellent.  But the tacos and delicious trio of salsas were what made me swoon - I had 4 of them (yes, 4) - the short rib, the cochinita pibil, the chicken mole colorado, and the veggie taco (with butternut squash and many other yummy things I can't remember).  Oh dear lord!  Epic deliciousness.  Trust me, you want to try these tacos
author: Semira J.

description:
Tacolicious was D-LICIOUS!

I'm sure there's plenty of "real" Mexican in the area... this place delivers on both ambiance and food.  A large colorful cheerful open restaurant with bar and stool seating, perfect for date night or just bringing your little one (yes, they're welcome here!).  

We were there during brunch time, so they had a fun menu with sparkling sangria and BLOODY MARIAs ($9), which my husband is still about its unique spicy peppery flavor.  Complementary chips and salsa were crispy, tasty, and addictive -- perfect for enticing you to order GUACAMOLE ($7.50), which was perfect creamy saltiness.  

Their main draw - TACOS, of course!  One for $3.95, 4 for $13, 10 for $31.  Unique flavors each served on 2 corn tortillas.  Enough filling on each to split onto the 2 corn tortillas and share with your dining partner.  Four tacos plus the chips, salsa, and guac were enough to feed both of us!  We had the FRIED ROCK COD with tangy cabbage, SHOT-AND-A-BEER BRAISED CHICKEN, COCHINITA PIBIL, and the BRAISED BEEF SHORT RIB, which was my favorite.  The meats were all well marinated, moist, and tender!  

So, okay, it's not traditional Mexican in a land of taquerias.  But it's delicious -- can't wait to go back and try out the other tacos!
author: Heather s.

description:
The food was good, the drinks were good, and the place itself isn't bad. They had some inventive tacos, including a butternut squash veggie taco and a beer-and-a-shot braised chicken taco. I loved the house margarita, and I'd like to come back and check out the tequila bar next door.

Immediate outside seating with heat lamps and the Dolores Park artwork was nice, especially since it looked like a madhouse inside. But we had to ask if we could be seated here instead of having it offered to us on this crowded night. Is it like the secret menu at In-n-Out or something? 

We spent $50 for two people, which is about what we spend at other sit-down Mexican places (Puerto Alegre). We got less food for more money, but this food was admittedly better than Puerto.

Despite it being good and different from the area standbys, it was still a bit too Marina in vibe for a girl who trends Mission.
author: Tara R.

description:
It's really easy to pass this place by - they don't have a sign out front, not one that I could see anyway.  Inside it's super cute.  I love the yellow tile floor with the star pattern.  We decided to sit outside on the patio since it was a nice day.  

The chips and salsa to start are fresh, spicy, and delicious - and free!  Yay, just the way it should be.  I was not impressed by my drink.  I can't find it on the on line menu, but it was something with champagne and it was a tomato color.  Expensive and gross.  I couldn't finish it and neither could my dining companion.  She tried though, because you shouldn't let alcohol go to waste.  Like my mother used to always tell me, there are thirsty people in other countries and it's a sin.  Or maybe that was hungry people.  Anyway, I digress.  We both ordered the tacos.  I got their vegetarian variety with a side of cheese and I have to say, I was impressed.  The tortillas were soft and fresh and the filling was imaginative and flavorful.  Vegetarian tacos that had some thought put into them - they weren't an afterthought.

I wouldn't say this is authentic Mexican food, but then again I've only been to Mexico a few times and I am no expert.  I would categorize it as Tex-Mex and yummy.  Try it!
author: Natalee F.

description: Love this location.  Came here for a friend's birthday.  We had a large party and we didn't give them any advanced notice.  They hooked us up in the back room, the service was awesome, and the food was delicious.  I'm docking a star though because for some weird reason they don't have the tortilla soup here, but they do at the one in the marina.
author: Jessica F.

description:
Tacolicious was pretty good and my husband and I walked away satisfied with our meal.  

Decor is nice, the stools aren't the most comfortable, but I'm guessing they don't want you lingering too long.

We tried the spicy shrimp appetizer which was okay, a little light on the shrimp.  And we tried the beet salad which would have been delicious except for the unusual choice to pair it with grapefruit.

The tacos, were good.  The traditional carnitas tacos had excellent flavor, and were the perfect amount of fillings.  

Our waitress was nice, not always around but nice, and it wasn't overly expensive. Overall a good experience.

Oh, and they have a really cool mural of Mission Dolores Park/High School on the patio wall.
author: Margaret I.

description:
Bar height tables, orthogonal aesthetics, moody lighting, Mission mural, and thousands of ball jars (look up at Mosto). Design that you and your date can look at and talk about. 

But you'll have to roll each other home. It's salted fat on a tortilla. The arteries say: never again! Not often, at least.
author: Mandy H.

description:
While hearty, our tacos (chicken mole, pork, short rib and beef) lacked the real flavor that one expects from a street taco, or any taco for that matter, although in the defense of Tacolicious, they do claim not to be a taqueria on their blog.  

The biggest highlight was the nicely designed space, with Mexican style tiles and modern artwork in the back private dining room, which fits the Valencia corridor a la the Mission Apple Store, or rather The Summit across the street, however, the design appears to have been more thoughtout than some of the menu items. 

A few of the items we sampled were off the mark, including the "semi-traditional" refried beans, which at $5.00, tasted quite traditional from a can.  The "chili con queso" from the "Side" portion menu also lacked oomph.  The description on the menu for this item reads "sustainable? no. local? nope. delicious? yep". The last description should be "delicious? only if you like 7-11 pump nacho cheese".

While Tacolocious will be a success, it clearly caters to a particular crowd, but given its location, it does need to lose its Marina District vibe, which caters to those seeking to spend stock sale gains for more atmosphere than authentic tacos, I would also lose the salad name "Marina Girl" , which is a little offensive to the neighborhood.  To pay homage to the new location and the great Dolores Park mural in the patio, perhaps call it "Hipster Hill" salad, as some call the sunny section of Dolores Park.  Given Tacolicious proximity to Mission Street and truer taquerias, those seeking better tasting tacos will stick to Mosto for drinks and then head over to a taqueria for a bite.
author: Rafael R.

description: Much like the Spanish invaded the warm tropical beaches of the Yucatán so too has Tacolicious conquered the concrete jungle of the Mission. Though instead of bringing enslavement and pox blankets, Tacolicious has given the public weak margaritas and tacos found delectable only to the tongues of the melanin deficient. But just like the Spanish, the modern day conquistador Tacolicious is using its clout to push out all the original inhabitants of the land while simultaneously exploiting the people it needs for its enterprise to flourish. Tacolicious overcharged my friend for his party by adding on services that he never requested nor was told the price of said services. In total I ended up paying $65 for 2 mediocre tacos and one tiny margarita that was mostly devoid of tequila. Even though the Mission Dolores is nearby, I still think Tacolicious is the biggest symbol of modern colonization in the Mission district.
author: Monica C.

description:
Not a bad addition to the 'hood!

With that said, I'm not sure I've ever seen so many high-heels in the Mission before, but the hubby and I had a lovely meal here, with surprisingly few hiccups for the first week of being open.

With a 45 minute wait time around 7:30, we went next door to Mosto and tried two tequila cocktails, La Paloma and the 'Lil Devil.  You know what we learned?  All cocktails made with tequila taste like margaritas.  So their "speciality cocktails" may as well be labeled "margarita with ginger beer" or "margarita with a grapefruit garnish."  That said, they were good.  The bar was a little bit of a scene, mostly because of people waiting to be seated next door.

We were seated well within the 45 minute quote and were immediately gifted some delicious homemade chips and nice salsa verde.  We tried the 4 for $13 tacos, which we thought was a great value.  Two fried local cod and two beef short ribs.  Both were pretty one-note-- a delicious note, but still one note.  The accompanying sauces really made them shine-- we especially liked the yellow habenero one.  We also had the fried plantains (yum) and a side of drunken beans and rice-a-licious (try ordering that with a straight face).  Everything was good.  Extra chips were granted on request and service was friendly and attentive.

I'm not sure I'm on board with a $4 can of Tecate-- you can get a draft Tecate for $2 down the block at Homestead.  $4 doesn't really go with the whole Mission thing.  We split the $7 Tall boy, which was a slightly better value, but still.  Come on.  Charge $3 for a can of beer-- you're making more than enough money on the tequila cocktails at $9 a pop.

A great spot for "fancy Mexican" food, or for sharing chips and Margs with your gfs.
author: Kristin P.

description: OMG I finally went there and I Have to say their food is DELICIOUS!! I love the fish tacos, the decor is awesome, the margaritas are fantastic! Only thing is parking can be a nightmare in the Mission, so ride your bike! But you'll be so stuffed from good food afterward that you probably won't be able to ride it home, haha. Super-fun place to go with friends!
author: Melissa J.

description:
Tacolicious I love you! I heard about you over and over again from my friends, but with all the new fancy restaurants opening up around the neighborhood you weren't on the top of my list. You should have been!

On my first try we came in kind of late, but we got served in time and powered down two pints of your amazing pomegranate margaritas before last call. 

Today we tried you again, and Brent served us. He was attentive, funny, and really gave us the scoop. His recommendation was the best thing I tried (the Taco of the Day)

Thank you Brent, get ready cause you just got yourself a new regular ;3
author: Cake S.

description:
The Mission is already full of delicious tacos, but this isn't a normal taco-joint. First of all, no burritos on the menu. Second, they use local organic and naturally raised meats. Third, they put together a space that is inviting, comfortable, family friendly, and fun. You'll pay more for these tacos, but personally I don't mind it for a well prepared meal in an enjoyable environment.

My favorite tacos are the cod, carnitas, and short rib. I always try their special of the week; sometimes they do a shrimp taco, which is awesome. The corn tortillas they get from La Palma are fluffy and delicious. They use two tortillas per taco and stuff them with toppings. I'd say a person with a normal appetite would get full with 3-4 of them. There's also a lot of appetizers to choose from. I usually get their guacamole to go with the chips, and the grilled squid is excellent. They make their own churros too, if you have room for dessert. 

They have a nice side patio for nice afternoons.  The mural of Mission High School and the SF skyline by Paul Madonna is pretty neat. You can find funny and thoughtful phrases hidden throughout the piece. The bar Mosto next door is also part of the establishment. The thousands of jars on the ceiling have little knick-knacks stowed away inside. Their house margaritas are pretty good. But the bar also has an enormous selection of tequilas. I usually just go with a Negra Modelo on tap.

I made several visits and found that the only time it isn't busy is when it opens at 11:30am. Then again, their kitchen is already cranking out catering orders by that time. In the evenings the bar is also totally packed with people waiting for a table. It's unfair to knock a restaurant for being crowded, since it's a sign that they're doing something right to attract and satisfy customers. Too bad they don't take reservations for small parties (only 12 or more).
author: Jermaine R.

description:
Tried Tacolicious with a friend, out of morbid curiosity, after hearing good things about it. A taco restaurant imported from the Marina HAS TO be bad, right? Maybe it was the tequila, but after our first bite into the tacos, we realized that hating it was going to be out of the question.

Hip atmosphere inside, with a great bar right next door, where we grabbed drinks and waited for our table. Went for the specialty cocktails which proved to be a good choice. The guacamole was sadly the lowest point of the meal. Not super flavorful, and not chunky enough for my tastes, however the portion they send out is generous.

Each of us tried the 4 fo $14 tacos. I tried the carnitas and the braised short rib tacos, which were flavorful and filling. The butternut squash taco was a new experience for me, one which I wholeheartedly enjoyed. The weekly taco was a delicious blend of onions and potatoes. Overall a surprisingly yummy dining experience!
author: Geno B.

description:
Oh hell yes.  $4 tacos?  Check.  1,000 different tequilas?  Check (okay, that might be an exaggeration).  Taco juice dripping down my arm?  Check (seriously, Tacolicious, how 'bout some wet naps?)  

Total satisfaction?  CHECK!
author: Jillian Y.

description:
The first time I tried to eat at Tacolicious, there was a 2 hour wait. I think I waited 2 hours to get into a screening of Star Wars one time. Anyway, that night, we decided to go elsewhere. Today we go there a little after 1 and got seated right away even though the place was a little busy.

I got the 4 tacos deal: 2 rock cod, 1 carnitas, and 1 short rib. We all got the same deal, so when the tacos were delivered they all came on long plates broken up by type. The carnitas and the short rib tacos were super delicious and had a lot of meat packed into a small package (that's what she said!) while the rock cod taco was too greasy and I ended up not eating one of mine. Everybody was in agreement over the fish taco and one of my other dining companions ate a chorizo potato taco which he said was great. SO, stick with the meat I guess. They start you off with chips and salsa which are the thick kind of chips with not too much salt and a medium heat salsa. Yummy!

Tacolicious is a cute restaurant which is a little on the small side, but does have seating outside as well as inside. The place is clean and tidy and warm and the wait staff are very friendly and attentive. I can't wait to come back here again and try some of the other taco choices!
author: Jason W.

description: Really juicy, delicious tacos! All 4 of my tacos were outstanding, and my friend agreed. Strawberry margarita was very tasty. Salsas and chips were fresh and delicious. Would be 5 stars if not so expensive.
author: A. Wolfram K.

description:
This is one of those places I want to like but just don't.  The seats are actually uncomfortable and they put so much stuff on the table you have no room for your food.  Why do we need a giant orange ceramic napkin holder?  And why am I asking that question when I leave a restaurant instead of thinking about the food?  I guess because the food was boring and a little underwhelming.   We tried the entire selection of tacos and I think if I was forced to pick my favorite it would be the fish taco.  But it's not enough to draw me back in. 
The server was really great.  No pressure to up sell and he was smiling and friendly. Actually everyone was friendly and the atmosphere was cheery. The other diners seemed to really be enjoying the food and atmosphere.  I wish I could say i did too.
author: Frank A.

description:
If you don't love their food here, I don't know if you have any taste buds.  Had the crispy tuna tartare with a bit of pink cactus margarita - absolute heaven!  The chips and salsa were alright.  My mom makes better ones at home, so it was a little lacking there.  Also, the chips and salsa came out AFTER I received my dish.

The atmosphere is nice and diverse.  It is a bit pricy, but not for the Mission.  The staff is very friendly and nice, however, it is a bit pretentious.
author: B L.

description:
I'm not as impressed as I wished I was... that's the problem.  I have been a BIG fan of the Tacolicious on Chestnut... I went there despite my disinterest?/disgust with Chestnut Street.  The tacos are that good.  I endured sitting too close to LOUD women talking loudly about themselves.  I thought the Mission location might be a way to enjoy that level of mad taco deliciousness without the Marina BS... not true on my first visit.  

My tacos were just not as good...yikes!...the drinks were great, bar was situated well, I don't know...

I'll try them again, the bar is super apealing looking.. I did not go in. Is it hard to duplicate something like tacos well.?..
author: Kerstin A.

description:
Looking for some bougie Mexican in the Mission?? Try this is out. 

Gorgeous space on Val btw 18th &19th, really cool floor. 

High end tequilas at their bar, Mosto, which is connected next door. Not a tequila fan but the bartender was nice enough to make a fruity rum concoction for me. 

Four tacos for $13 - not a bad deal. One for $3.95 & 10 for $30 also, I believe.

Now the one thing that I would say REALLY sets Tacolicious apart from ANY other mexican/latin restos in the mission - and this is really big in my book, because i loooooove this item - THEY SERVE A BEER-BATTERED FISH TACO. In fact, if I hadn't passed by and seen that one thing on the menu, I might've kept walking. 

That's right, folks. Now if I want to be healthier and super cheap and order a grilled albeit much more lackluster fish taco for $3, I can do that at Pancho Villa (and a few other spots), which I have long been doing. BUT there are no beer-battered fish tacos in the mission, people, i'm telling you!!! I have searched far and wide. As far as that goes, Tacolicious has a corner on the market. And they were right up there with some of the best I've had (As much as I hate to admit this, I love Rubios!!!!) 

Crowd was, as some have mentioned, a little more "dressed" than you might see at some neighboring spots (my boyfriend wore a track suit to dinner and felt a little under dressed). Sat at the bar & ate, server/bartender was hella chill. Pretty cheap eats - our drink bill was higher than our food bill. 30 min or less wait at 9pm on a sunday night. Will return for said fish taco shortly.
author: Shannon R.

description:
The carnitas taco was delicious. The fish, veggie and chicken ones, not so much.  The order was messed up. They also brought someone else's  food to our table and it sat there until we said we didn't order it, then they were walking around with it.  Seemed kinda amateur  hour or something.

The brussels sprouts were tasty, but not very many.

Update....for the farmers market location on thursday....

We had six tacos and the tres leche cupcake.  Very good, 3 carnitas, one beef, one veggie and ine chicken suiza,  Liked the truck a lot more
author: Foodlover B.

description:
I came here with a group of five friends.  We put our name on the waitlist and checked out the bar attached next door while we waited.  Our table was finally ready after we downed a carafe of Vino.

The chips and salsa were probably the best part of the meal.  We went through at least 4-5 baskets of the deliciously fried tortilla chips.  We also ordered the guac to start off, and it was heavenly!  Some of the best guac I've had recently.

We ordered two of the 10 tacos for $31.  We ordered 4 each of:
-Fried local rock cod: best of the bunch.  a large fried portion of fish goodness.  You've got to order this!
-Shot-and-a-beer braised chicken: a tad on the salty side, but my second favorite.
-Cochinita pibil: honestly not very memorable
-Traditional carnitas: a tad on the salty side too.

The taco's were a little too meaty for my taste.  Each taco was piled high with meat.  So you can't complain that they skimp on the meat.  However, I prefer my tacos with more of a balanced meat-to-salsa/veggie-ratio.

The butternut squash sounded intriguing, but my vote was vetoed, so I'd be willing to give Tacolicious another go to try some of the other tacos.

The interior of this place was cool and typical of Mission's new and hip eateries.  Lots of wood and metal adorn this shoppe.  The lighting is low and casual.  Fun place to come with friends. 

The taco's were just alright, so rather than call this place Tacolicious, I'd call it Taco-ok.  If you are looking for authentic Mexican street tacos, keep searching, because you won't find them here.  This place is more like fushion-mex.  I've definitely had better tacos elsewhere.
author: Matt S.

description: Went for sunday brunch and the food was YUMMY. They have an exstensive tequila menu which was of particular interest to me as I am a LOVER of this liquor. It was very good all the way around. The outdoor seating is pleasant and comfortable with heating. The wait staff was good but needed training. They could not answer Q's well about the menu, table numbers outwhitted the hostess. No one knew the name of the chef. But the food and beverage was worthy of another try.
author: The Style R.

description:
The food is great! 

The service is another story...the server seemed slammed. It took almost 10 minutes for her to even greet us and then another 15 minutes for us to get our drinks. 

It's also very LOUD!! Don't go here if you want to talk in your inside voice.
author: Pam W.

description:
I say "welcome" to 350+ Tequilas in the bar!  "Hola Taco" to $1.50 tacos at the bar.  "Bueno Sol" to an outdoor patio with heaters and a retractable roof for the winter!  

Did I mention 350+ Tequilas!   Two blocks from my house.  Giddyup.

I didn't even get to try the food - it was their bar opening night when I was there.  Who cares...it could be damn good Mexican food and it's going to have a fight to claim any type of taco status in the Mission.  So shooting for "licious" seems approachable.

Lets go back to 350+ Tequilas!   They need a tasting iOS app to keep track.  Hipsters, see if you can figure that out.  

Have a Tequila every day...or just 7 on Tequila Tuesday (sure to be a day there soon)!  You can still come for an entire year and still not get through them all.

Somebody should write a food review.  Regardless, this place will be a Mission institution before New Years.  See you there, I'll be at the cool little bar stools staring at the tequila and trying to count the mason jars nailed to the ceiling.
author: Nate G.

description:
In a taco mood, but feeling dainty? Then you've definitely come to the right place. 

I had the pick your own 4 taco platter, three out of the four were good. 
-carnitas
-beef short rib
-chicken en mole
-cochinita pibil

The carnitas taco was the high point, with cochinita pibil being the low (I took one bite and immediately regretted it). 

Overall, the service and food was pretty good.
author: MJ T.

description:
The food was great, it was the service that stunk.  I went there with a big group and we all ordered (on one tab) in groups of 2 or 3 people.  In the end we ordered about 7plates of 10 tacos per pair (e.g. 5 chicken, 2, carne asada, 2 veg, etc).  The server was cranky and short with us.  When our orders came up, all of the tacos came out batched by their type - so we had 10 chicken, 10 carne asada, etc.  per plate. When we were surprised by what arrived, the server snapped at us "you ordered this".   We had to pass 7 plates of tacos continuously around the table until everyone remembered what combo they ordered.  It was a pain and not handled well.   I felt like she didn't care because she (server) was going to get her tip built in no matter what.   

I would go back for the food but be cautious about going in a group of any kind.
author: Patty R.

description:
Just beginning to write this review is making me hungry.

This is my go-to place for fancier mexican fare in the city. I have not tried anything at Tacolicious that was not tailor-made for the gods. Shot-and-a-beer braised chicken tacos: pure heaven. Rice-olicious: OMG. Guacamole: I can't handle it. The tuna tostados: No really, I died awhile ago from happiness, no need for overkill... well OK. Churros: this can't be real. 

My only complaint is that some items are just so expensive, like the guac.
author: Jenny J.

description: Delicious!! My favorite tacos in the city. I've been here many times and they're very consistent with food and service. My go-to is the beer braised chicken, SO good! Also try the carnitas and short rib. Their guac is a bit pricey but also to die for. Top it all off with a margarita! This is place is so good that it's on our list of spots to bring out of towners, viva tacolicious!
author: Brigette A.

description: Apparently not all Tacolicious joints are created equal cause the Mission one was a giant disappointment.  Fish, carnitas, and pollo- all meh. The cod pieces were huge and the batter was a mushy mess. Mush should not be the first word in mind when biting into a fish taco.. Carnitas was meh and the pollo was flavorless. The best part of our meal were the apps- ceviche and plantains were delic. If you want your taco fix go to the one in the Marina- its awesome!
author: Ritu K.

description:
Oh T-lish, many a drunken night I have stumbled over to your doorstep for your amazing fish tacos & delicious churro dessert dish... I anticipate many more visits in the future, as much as my budget will allow, at least! 

I've tried quite a few of their dishes. Dined alone and in a big group, and they're always accommodating. The guacamole is creamy and refreshing, but could use a bit more kick. Chips & salsa are always overflowing and perfect. 

Of the tacos, the rock cod is by far the greatest. I also love the short rib, adobada, and some of their seasonal options like rajas con papas. The churro dessert comes with a warm chocolate dipping sauce that is GRAND. Lastly, we stopped in for brunch this past weekend and I def enjoyed the bistec con huevos, though it was a little smaller than I anticipated.
author: Trish A.

description:
Thank you Tacolicious for saving the evening for us.  After a fail by GRUB who took our reservation on OpenTable for Friday evening but was actually closed...we were fortunate to be welcomed with an immediate table at Tacolicious across the street.
What a nice surprise.  I can't say I would have ever tried this place, but now I will go back.  We had a tuna appetizer and two different tacos.  All were mouthwateringly delicious.  The service was fantastic too.
Sorry GRUB, your cool menu will not be enough to lure me back, especially when Tacolicious is right across the street.
author: Tammy N.

description:
This review is specifically for group dining in the private room.

We were a group of 11 people, and couldn't have been happier with our dinner last Saturday at Tacolicious. The private room is wonderful. Our only (small) gripe was that it was a bit chilly, so bring a warm jacket if you get cold easily. If your group isn't big enough to fill it up (I'm guessing that's 25+ people; it's a big room) you might share it with other groups, but it's a large space and it's not a problem at all. The group menu is excellent in terms quality of food; selection; and value. We all ate well -- including appetizers, tacos, and dessert -- for $29 per person, plus drinks, tax and gratuity. The service was excellent, both at the restaurant as well as organization before the event. Overall, I can't think of a better place for a large, affordable semi-private or private group dining in San Francisco.
author: David C.

description:
Friend: I bet you a shot of tequila there is a subway in LA
Me: There is no way LA has a subway system, that wouldn't even be economical for them

Bust out smartphones, I lose, which tequila to choose?

Me: Do you guys have Patron?
Bartender: That's not real tequila, we don't keep that crap here
Me (feeling slightly stupid): Well, what do you recommend?
Bartender: Here try Don Julio

After literally giving me a shot as a taster, this bartender has forever screwed me and my wallet over due to my tequila drinking tendancies. Now I can't turn back from the good stuff. Also, this place has Dos XX Lager on tap -- obvioulsy an immediate winner!

Besides the winning alcohol specialties, the food here is quite good although the veggie options are a little limited. Would love to see some veggie specials of the day, Tacolicious!
author: Raina B.

description:
Tacolicious is kind of a swank taco restaurant, if that makes any sense.  It came from the Marina, bringing good chips and queso along with their excellent tacos.  Mosto next door makes some nice margaritas--ask for a house on the rocks and you won't be disappointed.

The wait here can be extreme during dinner hours, so plan ahead or go during off-peak times.
author: Dan W.

description: I'd give this place 5 stars if the prices were a tad lower.  But you get what you pay for.  Every menu item I've tried is delicious, when I get a queso hankering this is the place I go to.  The tacos can be stretched farther if you split them up between their two corn tortillas.  A place I will never walk out of sober!
author: e w.

description:
Nice place, but the barstool setup was disappointing as we had nowhere to hang out coats. We arrived and were told the wait would be 45 minutes, so we went next door to Mosto for some drinks. *90* minutes later (we probably only waited that long because of the drinks affected our judgement), we finally got a table. The host was nice and kept apologizing and kept saying "your table is being prepared right now" or "we're just waiting for the party to leave" or some other excuse.

By then, we were all slightly cranky and definitely starving. We ordered the guacamole (meh), refried beans (meh), and the plantains (okay, nice that they're not overly greasy) to start. For the tacos, we got carnitas (good), rock cod (good), conchita (meh), and chicken mole colorado (the best of the lot). Pretty pricey for tacos, by the way. The sangria (pitcher) is pretty good. The chips and salsa are great.

I'd eat here again, but not if I have to starve myself waiting again. Definitely NOT for a "45 minute wait".
author: Maximillian M.

description:
I LOVE this particular tacolicious! This location is a lot larger and a lot nicer than the one in the marina. The design of the place plus their tequila bar next door reminds me of the bars and restaurants in NY. This place is fun and perfect for a "chill" friday night where you want to have a drink and good food with friends but not have to deal with drunk dancing morons. 

We sat at the bar and our bartender was so friendly and even let us try some of the many tequilas they have. The highlight of the night was sitting next to new friends who taught us so much about tequila! The clientele here are so much cooler!

I'm hoping to reserve the back room sometime in the future for a party! They even have a small outdoor area. SOLID in my book! I'll be coming back soon!
author: Jennifer C.

description:
There will be a wait for dinner. It will probably be around an hour.

I was hesitant about the ridiculous name, but I really liked this place. It was huge, first of all. The bar area was crowded and they serve some food there, but it's a separate kitchen from the main restaurant. That tasty looking al pastor spinning next to the bar? Not available when you're eating in the restaurant.

Bummer.

Drinks are good, nothing super-sweet.

The previous reviews about the carnitas were dead on. Possibly the best carnitas I've ever eaten.

Rock cod was done really well, but it's not very flavorful, so take advantage of the salsas.

The chorizo... not so much.

The salsas are very, very good.

Beet salad was good, but didn't need the dressing on top -- could have been a lot better with just a squeeze of lemon.
author: Ang F.

description:
This is the first time I have ever written a review on Yelp, but these folks went so far above and beyond the call of duty I felt I needed to share my experience with everyone.

I had picked up a to go order the other night of their fabulous taco pack for 6 to bring to a friend's birthday party.  When it came time to plating up the food and putting it out for everyone to enjoy I realized that they had left out their amazing salsas.  What good are chips and tacos without salsa???  I called to let them know and was handed over to the manager.  She absolutely insisted on sending someone over with the forgotten salsa.  I said that was not necessary, too far, etc., and that she could just add a credit to my bill.  She insisted, saying that they take customer service very seriously, that she wanted me to be completely satisfied and she would have the food delivered within 20 minutes.  

The doorbell rang and they delivered not only the salsa, but 3 big containers of it, along with extra chips, etc.  This was so amazing, none of us could believe it.  Sadly, customer service has been on a down hill slide for awhile, especially in restaurants, yet when a restaurant truly believes in what they do and actually go the extra mile, it definitely is worth noting, hence my review.  Their food is so absolutely delicious yet this is what is going to keep me coming back.  Well done Tacolicious and thanks again!!
author: Debbie s.

description:
I loved this place in the Marina. It was everything I wanted; trendy decor, hot blonde future MILFs, amazing guac and mediocre tacos. Then, something happened...they opened in the Mission and they lost the hot future blonde MILFs but kept the mediocre tacos. No bueno. 

Go elsewhere if you want delicious tacos. Come here if you want a good social atmosphere and drink selection.
author: Nick F.

description: Not particularly tasty tacos despite the pretty presentation. The albacore tostadas were good.
author: Jeannie T.

description: The tacos here are delicious!  After what seems liked infinite attempts (read: 5) the bf and I FINALLY ate at Tacolicious.  The previous four tries resulted in being told the wait was over an hour and us leaving.  This time. however. we were blessed by the restaurant gods and we got to sit immediately in their seated out door patio.  I had a paloma (grapefruit & tequila) and it was delicious!  We ordered the guac to share which was good but was definitely made better by mixing in some salsa for extra flavor.  I had two tacos - one chicken and one fried fish.  Both were AMAZING.  I totally understand why people wait over an hour to eat here.  I fully recommend Tacolicious for all your Mexican food (and drink) needs!
author: Liz H.

description:
Oh mannn great salsa for chips. GREAT habanero salsa and salsa verde. Not even going to spoil the surprises for you. You just need to try it y'all.

I just need some cilantro and onions on my tacos. The fillings aren't great.
author: Margaret S.

description:
Tacos are near the top of my personal food pyramid, and living in the Mission is quite satisfying. I have a wide varitey of taco joints, and then came this place.
How could a place named "Tacolicious" be any good. The name itself rolls off the tongue as if Paris Hilton is lazily, pompously blurting it out. How could a place named by that Hilton slut be any good.

It is.

Quite good in fact.

Something for everyone. Spicy, mild, standard, or flavorful, there is a taco for your appetite. Other reviewers will dive into the details of which is there favorite and why. I suggest you go order your go-to taco and try something you would not expect. You won't be disappointed, but you will still hear Paris say Tacolicious in your head when you blurt it out.

As for drinks, to each his/her own, but the pricey classic margarita pitcher was perfectly mixed.

Great to see lots of families with the early dinner crowds. Don't be afraid to sit outside as the heat lamps to the trick.
author: J S.

description:
Recommended Dishes: Order a few taco platters for sharing. The chorizo y potatoes taco is especially delicious. Others in my group also loved the pork belly taco (a special that night).

Atmosphere: Bustling, festive. May be on the loud side for some.

Cost: Slightly pricey for Mexican food, but the overall experience and atmosphere justify the cost. Money-saving tip: order wisely! Two-three tacos per person is plenty.

Wait-Time: Long wait, even on a random Wednesday night. No reservations for parties less than 10. Luckily you can grab a drink at Mosto, the tequila bar next door, while you wait.
author: Katie R.

description: I am a huge fan of mexican food and these tacos deliver in every way. Not often that I take the first bite and say WOW but this food did that for me. Had the short rib taco, chicken special and the carnitas. All three were great. The drunken beans were good but did not impress and neither did queso. Those were missed opportunities. Fun environment and service was very good. This is a must do if you are in the neighborhood!
author: Mark Q.

description: Tacos were delicious especially the short rib and the carnitas. Great drinks selection also.
author: Mark P.

description:
Eh. I've been to Tacolicious' other location in The Marina and after checking out this one recently, I'm just not that impressed, really. Big ups to the tequila selection here, though.

With their tacos at a little over $3 a pop, I was expecting something jaw-dropping, but that $3 just pays for the ambiance of the place, I guess. I love mexican food, and I'm glad I got to try out Tacolicious, finally...but I'll stick to my local taquerias and taco trucks. for my taco fixes when I need them...which is everyday.
author: Trav M.

description:
Having lived in San Diego for four years, I have always felt that SF/NorCal Mexican food doesn't measure up well to what you can find in SoCal.

That said, Tacolicious is definitely a major exception. The shot-and-a-beer braised chicken, cochinita pibil and guajillo braised beef short rib tacos were perfection. The tacos were only made better with their excellent salsas. I would have happily given Tacolicious five stars, but the fried rock cod didn't do justice to the Baja-style fish tacos you find in SoCal and Mexico.

I am looking forward to trying the mole and filet tacos very soon. Thanks, chef Telmo!
author: Steven W.

description:
A little loud for my tastes, but if you like bars and music you have to shout over, then you'll be okay.
The place is so hip it doesn't have a real sign outside, so it's easy to miss. Once inside you'll see a symbol of a taco with a "lish" after it. That means you have arrived.

If you are eating gluten free, unfortunately the only taco you can have is carnitas, but it was as tasty as a carnitas taco can be. (Please stop putting cubes of fat in there though)

Portions are small for the price, but if you have a nice tech job then you probably don't need to worry about it.

Ceviche was way overpriced (avoid).

The salsa was something they can be proud of, though it could have a little more bite.

Drunken beans need work. Need more flavor (bacon? peppers?)

Overall, yeah I might go back.
author: Davo W.

description:
I don't know what to make of this place.  It is not a gringo taco haven, but I am definitely missing some of the enjoyable elements of ordering a good street taco like not having to wait 1.5 hours for a table.  

On one hand, they have some decent menu choices, and the price is right.  On the other hand, the food could have been so much higher in quality.  Case in point, the fish taco was pretty much a taco stuffed with soggy filet o' fish like textured fish.  The squid veracruz smelled kind of fishy.  My meat tacos were pretty solid and nicely portioned, and I would probably stick to those.  Also, the waitress lumped our orders together (we had a table of five and ordered the max amount of tacos).  So it was not a bad deal.

Overall, I am lukewarm about this place and actually prefer Nopalito for my high end street taco fare.
author: Liaty Z.

description:
i came here with very low expectations because i was always under the impression that it was just a very hipster place (i mean... tacolicious as the restaurant name???) with pricey mediocre food 

i was surprised just how many people were there with over an hour wait for a table but luckily seats at the bar opened up. my fiancé and i tried the taco of the day, (braised short rib with onion, cilantro, and some other stuff) the fried rock cod, traditional carnitas, and the shot and beer braised chicken. i thought the presentation of the tacos all being laid out on a long plate was really nice. aside from the chicken taco, all the other ones were REALLY good! i have a habit of comparing taco prices to the $1.50 taco truck ones so $4-$5 tacos seems a bit extreme, but these tacos were way more filling to the taco truck ones so i did not mind.

despite how packed this place gets and how horrible it is to find parking in the mission, id be back!
author: Katherine C.

description:
Great food but a bit overrated, I think. And the wait -- my God.

I've been to the Mission location a few times and have always had a great experience. The service is speedy, the tacos done well, and the tequila selection would satisfy most palates. The sauces make a great addition to whatever assortment of tacos you're eating -- the spicier the better. I definitely recommend whatever pork tacos they have.
author: Rudy R.

description:
a step below lolo and 3 steps above your normal taqueria 

i.e. albacore tuna tacos with avocado

& lots of rose wine

they close outdoor seating @ 8:30pm but are open until midnight on weeknights which is nice!!!!
author: Sonya Z.

description:
The Queso is delicious, cheesy, perfection. Honestly, the Queso alone is enough to keep me coming back. Along side the chips and salsa, you can't go wrong. The tacos are fantastic too. 

Since you already blew your workout today on the Queso, you should probably top your meal off with the churros and chocolate dipping sauce, right? Definitely. 

One star off for not taking reservations. Be prepared to wait.
author: Daniel K.

description:
This is a nice addition to the neighborhood for those times when you're in the mood for Mexican food but want your tacos yuppified and with table service. 

If you're not drinking, the prices are pretty good -- $13 for 4 tacos, which is a good amount for 2 people if you add in some appetizers, which are also decently priced.  There are 8 taco choices, but unfortunately only one is vegetarian.  Some day, we will have more than 12.5% representation on omnivore menus, but I digress.

The waiter was super nice, but it seems like they're still working out some kinks, so if you're very particular about service, you may want to wait a while.  For example, we ordered tacos, the beet salad, and the plantains --- the tacos came out right away, then the salad about 20 minutes later, then the plantains a few minutes after that.  Kind of a weird order.  I also asked for the veg tacos to be separated from my friend's meat-filled ones, but they came out together, and I had to pretend I didn't notice the tortillas for my tacos soaking up the meat juices from hers.  Drinks were kind of slow as well (but really good).      

In short, definitely worth trying if you're in the mood to splurge on tacos and margaritas.  There was a 45-minute wait for an indoor table on a Tuesday night at 6:45, but no wait to sit outside, which was decently warmed by heat lamps and probably better for conversation anyway.
author: Mara E.

description:
Yes, the Mission is filled with tons of choices of food. Although I love good old taqueria's I'm still open to trying a not so authentic place. By the way, for anyone bashing restaurants like these, I'm shocked that you could not guess that the name itself would be.

Tacolicious is a fun and open restaurant. I noticed they had outside seating which would be perfect on a sunny SF day. The drinks are a little high. I was hoping they would have some type of happy hour? *If anyone knows if they do, please comment and let me know :) 

The shot-and a beer chicken taco was delicious. I really liked the flavors. My sister had the fish tacos and she said they were fresh and tasteful too.

The service was kind of slow, but the servers themselves were friendly and non-rushing. We didn't order a bunch of stuff, we wanted to try it out. They were still super nice to us.

I will come back here, I'm glad it's in the Mission so I don't have to go to the Marina (meaning I never would have). Calm down, Tacolicious definitely won't be a competition for our beloved authentic taquerias. Until then, eat on!
author: Sarina I.

description:
I've heard of Tacolicous from the Marina folks for some time and was definitely curious but not curious enough to drive to the other side of the city. 

I must say they knew what they were talking about. It was delicious! I love the tuna tostada - I needed to get 2 orders, it was that good!

The service was good - our waiter recommended the sangria which did not disappoint. 

I'm craving it now!
author: Monica S.

description: The chips and salsa were the best! Had two tacos- the short rib beef and the cod- super tasty and very filling. Great atmosphere as well.
author: Penny C.

description: The Short rib taco is one of my favorite tacos in the world.  Load up salsa on it and you are good to go.  And the calamari App is also amazing.
author: Miles C.

description: Great Food! Went in there at 2 with my mom, and it tasted really good. We had the veggie taco, short rib and pacific cod. The cod was my favorite then the short rib, then the veggie one.
author: Riley M.

description:
I've been waiting to try this place for a long time. Came here today with some friends and we were seated right away  We had 4 tacos to split and I ordered the baby back rib snack dish and split that too. The portions were not proportional to the menu price. You can easily get triple the size of the food there at a much affordable price somewhere else. The ribs were delicious though even though they were really small. 
What really bothered me was that the waiter reached over my shoulder to pick up my plate. I was so caught off guard I didn't get to take the last pear stick off the plate :( other than that our main waitress Emily? (or that's the name that was on the receipt), was really nice and so was the staff, or so they seem to appear. Honestly I don't think I would come back, on account that it is a good distance from my house and I don't go to the Mission often and I'd prob rather just travel down to S.SF and get a good set of tacos there.
author: Alex T.

description:
I've walked by tacolicious many times and wondered what place this was, since the signage is not obvious. The hubby and I went at 5:45 PM on Saturday, and there was already a 30 min wait for a table inside. We opted to sit outside, so we only had to wait a few minutes. 

The chili con queso starter was delicious. Tacos themselves were pretty good but not too memorable.

The "taco" that the hubby and I still crave is the chocolicious taco - a waffle shell with vanilla ice cream and some frozen chocolate syrup... similar to the choco taco of our childhood, but so much better! We'll be back.
author: Erin Y.

description:
Went here on Saturday, 18 Feb around 6:30pm  4 people

Very friendly greeting and told about an hour wait.  Headed to Mosto and although the bartender was cheerful, he wasn't extremely attentive (chatting with a coworker getting off shift).  Mixed a nicely balanced Margherita however.

We only ended up waiting 30min.  The server was awesome.  Just the right amount of happy, and quick to get us sorted with more drinks and offered to start us off with some queso or guacamole.  We went for the queso (which was pretty tasty and went fast).  None of us had been here before and we just told her to hook us up with 12 of her favorite tacos, and she didn't hesitate and went for it.

I have to say, the tacos were very good but the different meat ones all kind of tasted the same.  The fish was very good and had some distinct flavor compared to the others.  The chicken one we had was their "taco of the week" and was also good - the right amount of spicy.

The trio of salsas that came with them were excellent.  They went from a mild to a super spicy.

Fairly noisy, but still easy to talk. A good lively space, with a fun atmosphere.

The reason for the three stars:  I'd be happy to come back here, and I can't fault the service, but the food isn't something that I'd crave to come back for.  Don't get me wrong, we all enjoyed our meal, but no one was particularly 'wow'd' by the tacos.
author: R. S.

description: Phenomenal every time. A+ on the tacos and the best guac as well. The margaritas are perfect. Sometimes there's a bit of a wait, but it's well worth it. Usually you can find a spot at the bar to grab something. A must hit spot if you are in the mission district. T lish in the mish NOM
author: Amanda M.

description: They give you three different sauces to use on your tacos if you so wish. You can use one, two, all three, or even none. Sometimes I only use one. Also, I first came here roughly 65 years after the end of World War II.
author: Ryan L.

description: We were very excited to try this place but were completely disappointed the food was not as good service was really slow and everything is definitely overpriced! Never again will this be an option
author: Cendy A.

description: Amazing tacos! Great, unique selection with good portions for a decent price. I got the Baja Cod and short rib tacos and they were amazing!!! I'll definitely be coming back. Only weird thing about the place was the loud rave music they were playing in the background. Felt like I should be eating the tacos while dancing on a table top with lights all around me... Wait, that actually sounds really fun!
author: Alexandra F.

description: My favorite is the rock cod taco. Usually order two and I'm good (with a cold one of course!). My friend and I ordered the laiola's pan con chocolate for dessert and I would not recommend it at all. Looked unappetizing, small pieces of toasted baguette with a lump of chocolate. Gave us a good laugh though. Happening atmosphere, lots of good people watching. Noise level is high so I wouldn't come to have an intimate conversation. They stop seating people outside at 9 due to noise. Very long wait (75 mins) on a Saturday night.
author: Jasmine B.

description: While always packed, tacolicious is one of my favorite restaurants in San Francisco. I highly recommend the shortrib tacos and the shot and a beer chicken tacos. The cheese dip is also very good. Their salsa is fresh and minty I love it! Be prepared during lunch or dinner to have at minimum 45minutes wait.
author: Tory C.

description: Over hyped and WAY overpriced Tacos. Store bought tortillas.... Open your eyes sheople! So many better and cheaper taco options in the city.
author: Shane B.

description: Food was great! Service was ABYSMAL. I will never go back for sit-down brunch, dinner or anything else. It was tempting not to leave a tip at all. Our server was blatantly rude, unhelpful and disrespectful. Recommend the veggie tacos, carnitas tacos and the plantain appetizer. I had the "El Jardin" gin drink, which was okay, but not great.
author: Alessandra S.

description: A work group of about 12 of us went for dinner here on a Friday night. Service was decent, food was ok (yes, only ok). However, this review is about the simple fact that 6 of got some sort of food poisoning or stomach flu and spent several days sick to our stomachs. I don't think I've thrown up that hard since I was a kid. I don't know what they are doing at Tacolicious, but they definitely need to improve their standards in a big way.
author: Alex L.

description:
Met up with a few friends here at 7:30 on a Wednesday night.  Found out there was an hour wait, which is longer than I'd normally be down with, but we were waiting for one more in our party anyway so decided to gut it out.  Luckily Mosto, a tequila bar, is next door and connected to the restaurant, so we posted up there and waited with some drinks until the hostess came to collect us (as an aside, Mosto has awesome margaritas, and though crowded is not a bad place to wait for a table).

Once we sat down everything was gravy.  We demolished the chips, which were readily replenished.  Their salsa is excellent and unique.  We ordered an assortment of tacos and drinks, and although I can't vouch for all of the taco types, the vegetarian tacos and rock cod tacos were both excellent.  Our waiter was cool and the vibe was a nice mix of energetic but not overwhelmingly loud.  A fun experience.

If I were to do this again I'd go for lunch or earlier in the evening in order to avoid the wait for a table.  Aside from that though, this place was pretty awesome, lives up to the hype.
author: Michael M.

description: Loved my experience here. Ordered the 10 tacos for 30$ with a few other people - I love that it provides a chance to try lots of things on the menu. Had to make a reservation because it was very crowded on a Saturday night so beware. This place is lively - come here for a celebration, not an intimate conversation.
author: Stefanie S.

description: Good food, good margaritas. I only take away a star because it was really loud and cramped. But the tacos had a lot of meat on them!
author: Emily W.

description:
Pros:
Generally agreeable food
Variety in food and drink
Down-to-earth
Cute outside seating
Free chips and salsa

Cons:
Food is hit-or-miss
Overpriced
Weak drinks

Up to you:
Family-friendly
Tequila for days
author: Alex G.

description:
Seeing as though I had to have every taco within a 2-mile radius of where I was staying when I visited, I went here with some friends and was delighted. We were going for beers, but then someone said they have a special that you get a Tecate, a tequila shot, and a taco for $10. TEN BUCKS WE SAID? Yes, he answered. EVERY DAY? Yes, every day. LIKE EVEN TODAY, EVERY DAY? Yes. 

I had the carnitas taco and it was great. Good chips and solid (dark) salsa on the table as well, always a plus. I liked the busy but not too busy bar atmosphere and great location.
author: Lauren C.

description: Eh. Stick to the real taquerias in the Mission -- they have better tasting food and are more affordable (and are filled with less Marina types).
author: Priscilla M.

description:
Honestly, I thought I would hate this place- but I ended up loving the food, drinks and atmosphere at the Mission location
